encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be further explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or minuscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: PG#[Emblem 26]

Ambitious Apes
(Emblem 26)
AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

A dreadful fate awaits those who try to move above their station, this emblem warns. Demonstrating her familiarity with an array of historical, biblical, mythological, and sources, Pulter shows how this lesson applies across space and time: from overly ambitious Roman emperors to powerful Assyrian queens; from Old Testament Israelite rulers to apes who inappropriately dress in human clothes. To see how all overly zealous ascents to power will necessarily be crushed, one simply needs to look at imperial conquests (like Spain’s conquest of Muslim territories) that lead to defeat. Pulter also directs her vision of the cycling of authority and its vanquishing to contemporary politics, mourning the loss of the pre-war English government and condemning “one O” (implicitly, Oliver Cromwell) for wreaking death and destruction on England in the civil war. Written during the Protectorate, the poem seems to ask with bitter glee: what nemesis awaits the horrific political overreaching of our own day?

app.rdg: 26Thoſe that imployed are the Apes to catch
Those thatwho employéd are the apes to catch,
The places where they Haunt they Uſe to watch
The places where they haunt they use to watchApe-catchers routinely keep an eye on the apes’ usual habitation (“haunt”);
Stockings, and Cloths, abo^ut the Ground they Scatter
Stockings and clothes about the ground they scatter.
Then inſtantly the Apes begin to chatter
Then instantly the apes begin to chatter;
And beeing Ambitious to bee in the &ff;aſhion
And being ambitious to be in the fashion
Just as wee imitate our neighbour Nation
(Just as we imitate our neighbor nationFrance, commonly known as setting fashion trends at the time),
They draw them on, the Huntsmen then they See
They draw them onThe apes pull on the clothes. The huntsmen then they see;
Then every Ape begins to take A tree
Then every ape begins to takeclimb a tree.
But up they could not get for all their pains
But up they could not get for all their painsefforts;
They Strait were caught and led away in Chains
They straight were caught and led away in chains.
Thus thoſe which took a Town once from the Moors
Thus those which took a town once from the Moors
Through their Ambition were inſlav’d to Boores

Through their ambition were enslaved to boorspeasants, especially Dutch or German; sometimes used pejoratively. This couplet possibly alludes to the Dutch conquest of Gibraltar from Spain in 1607; the Spanish (“those which took a town” in the preceding line) had overthrown Moorish (North African Muslim) rule of Gilbraltar in 1492 (Eardley)..
Symirimus that was old Ninis Love

Semiramis, that was old Ninus’s loveIn Assyrian mythology, Semiramis is a goddess and queen to Ninus, founder of Nineveh, after whose death she founded Babylon and led victorious armies until, opposed by her son, she took the form of a dove and flew away.,
T’was her Ambition turnd her to a Dove
’Twas her ambition turned her to a dove.
Crook’d backs Ambition made five Monarchs Yield
Crook’d-Back’s ambition made five monarchs yieldCrook’d-Back, or crookback, was a nickname applied to Richard III, who overcame five monarchs in his rise to power.,
Whose Score hee pay’d again in Boſworth &ff;ield
Whose score he paid again in Bosworth fieldAt the Battle of Bosworth (1485), Richard III was killed by Henry Tudor, the future Henry VII..
Ambition made one O his Soveraign Kill

Ambition made one OWhat seems like an emotional exclamation can also signify Oliver Cromwell’s first initial; Cromwell led the Parliamentarians who killed King Charles I during the English Civil War. his sovereign kill,
And to mak’t good much Inocent blood to Spill
And to mak’tmake it good, much innocent blood to spill.
But ther’s a Nemuſes that will look Down
But there’s a NemesisIn Greek mythology, personification of the gods’ disapproval, jealousy, and retribution. that will look down
On all Uſurpers of their Maſters Crown
On all usurpers of their masters’ crowncrowns.
Soe Jezabell bid furious Jehew See

So Jezebel bid furious JehuJezebel, as the widow of Israel’s King Ahab, was killed by Jehu, who became king; before her death, Jezebel says to Jehu, “Had Zimri peace, who slew his master?” (2 Kings 9:31). see
The Curſed end of Nimries Treacherie
The curséd end of Zimri’s treacheryIn the Bible, Zimri is a captain who kills the king of Israel and makes himself king; he himself in turn is defeated and killed (2 Kings 9:30–31)..
Photion the Royall &ff;amily Subdued

Phocion the royal family subduedOne faction of the Athenian leadership accused Phocion (an Athenian general and statesman, 402-318 BCE) of enabling the death of Antipater (the Macedonian statesman); Phocion was put to death for treason. Pulter alters her likely source (Plutarch) by crediting Phocion’s guilt, when Phocion was generally remembered as a just and moral leader. See Plutarch, The Lives of the Noble Grecians and Romans, trans. Thomas North (London, 1579), pp. 797-814.,
And in their Princely blood his hands imBruwedpart of “m” appears added later (changing “in” to “im”); “u” appears written over an earlier letter
And in their princely blood his hands imbruedPhocion’s hands are stained or steeped in the royal family’s blood, or (in another sense) infected by it.,
Which horrid Action hee and ^his all hisstruck-through with multiple horizontal lines Rued
Which horrid action he and hisPhocion and his supporters/family all rued.
Andronicus that made his Soveraign Bleed

AndronicusAfter defeating the Goths, the Roman general Titus Andronicus gave permission to sacrifice the eldest son of Tamora, queen of the Goths, to appease the souls of his dead sons, and thereby unleashed a series of horrific acts of revenge., that made his sovereign bleed,
Cryed out at Last don’t bruiſe A bruiſed Reed
Cried out at last, “Don’t bruise a bruiséd reed.”
Soe Diocles the fateall Boar puld down

So Diocles the fatal boar pulled downDiocletian (also known as Diocles) was Roman emperor from 284 to 305, a position he achieved in part by killing Aper (Latin for “boar”), thus fulfilling the prediction that he would become emperor only after he killed a boar. See, for example, Fletcher and Massinger, The Prophetess, in Francis Beaumont and John Fletcher, Comedies and Tragedies [London, 1647]). Diocletian was the first Roman emperor to abdicate his position voluntarily. Thanks to Sam Nguyen for information in this note.
And triump’h’d[?]n“d” partly blotted, as is letter that follows, possibly “o”; above latter is ascending slash his Murther’d Maſters Crown
And triumphed in his murdered master’s crown,
Till finding it too heavie lay’d it by
Till, finding it too heavy, laid it by;
But yet forstruck-through with multiple horizontal lines yet for all hee by the Sword did Die
But yet, for alleven though he set aside the crown; or possibly, for his crimes, he by the sword did die.
Pompias ambition would noe Superiour have
Pompey’s ambitionGnaeus Pompeius Magnus, known as Pompey the Great, formed the First Triumvirate with Caesar and Crassus, but disagreement with Caesar resulted in civil war. would no superior have;
Hee lost his hopes in Ægypt found A grave
He lost his hopes, in Egypt found a gravePompey, defeated at the battle of Pharsalus, fled to Egypt, where he was murdered..
Cæſar noe Equall ever would abide
Cæsar no equal ever would abideJulius Caesar, Roman dictator, was murdered (as the next line indicates) in a conspiracy led by his senators.;
Hee had his Aime Yet byin different hand from main scribe the Senate Died
He had his aim, yet by the senate died.
Ambition made the Trumviry end
Ambition made the trumvirian association of three magistrates for joint administration; here, the First Triumvirate (see note above on “Pompey’s ambition”) end
When each to other Sacrificed his &ff;reind
When each to other sacrificed his friend.
Ambition made the Ephory give or’e
Ambition made the ephoryIn ancient Greek, “ephor” refers to a board of magistrates in some divisions of ancient Greece (Dorian states). give o’er
And kick’d King, Lords, & Comons, out of doors

And kicked king, lords, and commons, out of doorsAfter the civil war ended, Parliamentarians in England restructured the government and abolished the titles designating kingship and the representative bodies of the House of Lords and House of Commons..
Thus all Confuſion from Ambition Springs
Thus all confusion from ambition springs:
Apes would bee men, and all men, would bee Kings
Apes would be men, and all men would be kings.
Then by this Emblem it doth plain apear
Then, by this emblem it doth plain appear,
T’is best for every one to keep his Sphere.
’Tis best for every one to keep his spheresocial station, place, or position; domain in which one’s activities or faculties find scope.
